Graphical abstract CdS nanowires (NWs)-carbon nanotube (CNT) 1D–1D nanocomposites (CdS NWs-CNT NCs) have been fabricated via a very simple, room temperature self-assembly method, which is afforded by electrostatic attractive interaction between positively charged CdS NWs and negatively charged CNT in an aqueous solution. The CdS NWs-CNT NCs exhibit enhanced photoactivity toward selective reduction of aromatic nitro organics as compared to CdS NWs and their analogue CdS NWs-graphene, thus promoting us to rationally utilize carbon materials to design more efficient carbon-semiconductor composite photocatalyst instead of plunging into the “graphene gold rush,” similar to the case of CNT. One-dimensional CdS nanowires-carbon nanotubes nanocomposites (1D–1D CdS NWs-CNT NCs) with different weight addition ratios of CNT have been synthesized by a very simple room temperature self-assembly method, which is afforded by electrostatic attractive interaction between positively charged CdS NWs and negatively charged CNT in an aqueous solution. Importantly, the CdS NWs-CNT NCs exhibit remarkably enhanced photoactivity toward selective reduction of aromatic nitro organics in water under visible light irradiation as compared to bare CdS NWs. The significantly enhanced photoactivity is attributed to the integrated factors of the unique 1D–1D morphology associated with CdS NWs and CNT, the efficient retardation of recombination of the photoexcited electron–hole pairs, and the enhanced visible light absorption intensity. Besides, the CdS NWs-CNT NCs exhibit higher photoactivity than CdS NWs-reduced graphene oxide (CdS NWs-RGO NCs), toward selective reduction of aromatic nitro organics. Therefore, this work not only offers a very simple room temperature approach to synthesize highly efficient 1D semiconductor-1D CNT composite photocatalyst, but also gives an example that RGO cannot readily manifest its unique and prominent advantage over CNT for specific photocatalytic application, thus underpinning the importance of rationally utilizing the carbon materials (e.g., 1D CNT, 2D RGO) to design more efficient carbon-semiconductor composite photocatalyst. Keywords CdS nanowires Carbon nanotubes 1D–1D nanocomposite Visible light photocatalysis Selective reduction 1 Introduction One-dimensional (1D) semiconducting nanostructures, such as nanorods, nanowires, and nanotubes, lie at the heart of current research on nanometer scale science and technology and often display high chemical reactivity because of their low dimensionality and high surface-to-volume ratio [1–4]. Recent years have seen their extensive potential applications in numerous fields, e.g., photodetectors, light waveguides, solar energy conversion, lithium batteries, gas sensing, and photocatalysis [1–9]. In contrast to nanoparticles or bulk materials, 1D structural material has unique advantages as promising photocatalysts [10–15]. For example, the 1D geometry leads to a fast and long-distance electron transport [10]. In addition, the light absorption and scattering can be obviously enhanced because of the high length-to-diameter ratio of the 1D structure [14]. As an important II−VI semiconductor, CdS is an n-type semiconductor with a direct band gap of 2.4eV, corresponding well with the solar spectrum [16–18]. CdS is shown to have size-dependent electronic and optical properties [19,20], and diverse applications, such as biological sensors, solar cells, field-effect transistors, lasing and waveguide material, environment purification, and hydrogen evolution [21–29]. Many studies have been devoted to manipulating the size, morphology, and crystal structure of CdS materials and, particularly, various 1D CdS nanostructures, e.g., CdS nanotubes [30], nanowires [31], nanorods [32] and nanobelts [33]. Among them, the CdS nanowires have received considerable attention as a class of 1D novel photocatalytic materials [15,34]. Therefore, it is of significant interest to investigate the potential applications of such CdS NWs based materials in heterogeneous photocatalysis. On the other hand, carbon nanotubes (CNT) represent another type of non-metal-oxide 1D material and have received growing attention due to their superior physicochemical, mechanical, and electronic properties [35–38]. They are mechanically robust and thermochemically stable with high elasticity and high tensile strength, offering various potentials in sensors, electrocatalysts, energy conversion, environmental remediation, and catalysts [36–42]. We and others have shown that 1D semiconductor modified with CNT can exhibit improved optical, physical, and electronic properties, indicating their potential applications in photocatalysis [10,43,44]. There have been also several reports on synthesizing CdS NWs-CNT nanocomposites (NCs), while the synthesis approaches employed in these works are experimentally fussy [44,45]. For example, Hu and co-workers reported encapsulating CdS NWs inside CNT by calcinating a mixture of activated carbon and CdS powders at 1150°C under the N2 atmosphere [44]. Han et al. [45] have synthesized CdS NWs-CNT NCs in the anodic aluminum oxide (AAO) template nanochannels via sequentially electrodepositing CdS NWs and chemical vapor depositing CNT. It is expected that the nanocomposites could enhance the stability of CdS NWs in harsh environments and thus improve their performances in optical and optoelectronic devices. However, to the best of our knowledge, there are few investigations focused on the synthesis of CdS NWs-CNT NCs for applications in artificial photocatalysis, particularly for selective organic synthesis to fine chemicals. The integration of CdS NWs and CNT in a proper fashion could combine the respective advantages of these two 1D materials, which could be utilized as efficient photocatalyst with enhanced photoactivity performance. Herein, we employ a simple, room temperature self-assembly approach to synthesize the CdS NWs-CNT nanocomposites (NCs), which is afforded by substantial electrostatic attractive interaction between positively charged CdS NWs and negatively charged CNT in an aqueous solution. This approach simply utilizes the natural opposite surface charge of CdS NWs and CNT without the need of additional polyelectrolytes to modify the materials surface properties. The as-obtained CdS NWs-CNT NCs exhibit remarkably higher photoactivity than bare CdS NWs toward selective reduction of nitro organics in water under visible light irradiation. The significantly enhanced photoactivity can be attributed to the unique 1D–1D morphology associated with CdS NWs and CNT, the efficient retardation of recombination of photoexcited electron–hole pairs, and the enhanced visible light absorption intensity. In particular, we have also compared the photoactivity of CdS NWs-CNT NCs with that of CdS NWs-reduced graphene oxide (CdS NWs-RGO NCs) fabricated by the similar electrostatic self-assembly strategy. The results show that CdS NWs-CNT NCs exhibit higher photoactivity than CdS NWs-RGO NCs toward selective reduction of nitro organics. Therefore, this work not only offers a very simple electrostatic self-assembly approach to synthesize 1D semiconductor-1D CNT composites as highly efficient visible-light-driven photocatalyst toward selective reduction process for fine chemicals synthesis, but also gives an example that RGO (also called graphene) cannot readily manifest its unique and prominent advantage over CNT for a specific photocatalytic application. Although an absolutely strict comparison between CNT and RGO on enhancing the semiconductor photoactivity is hardly reached because it is difficult to ensure all other factors influencing the photocatalytic performance are identical in contrast test, our current study highlights that, so far, it is hard to clarify whether RGO is wholly superior to its carbon allotrope, CNT, for the use in photocatalysis. This fact consequently informs that ongoing research efforts should be rationally paid to how to sufficiently utilize the carbon materials to enhance the semiconductor photoactivity instead of plunging into the “graphene gold rush,” similar to the case of CNT. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Sodium diethyldithiocarbamate trihydrate (C5H10NNaS2·3H2O), graphite powder, ethylenediamine (C2H8N2), nitric acid (HNO3), hydrochloric acid (HCl), cadmium chloride (CdCl2·2.5H2O), (3-aminopropyl) triethoxysilane (C9H23NO3Si, APTES), ammonium formate (HCOONH4), potassium persulfate (K2S2O8), phosphorus pentoxide (P2O5), hydrogen peroxide, 30% (H2O2), potassium permanganate (KMnO4), and ethanol (C2H6O) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All materials were used as received without further purification. Deionized water that was used in the synthesis was obtained from local sources. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Treatment of carbon nanotubes. Carbon nanotubes (CNT) were obtained from Shenzhen Nanotech Port Co., Ltd., China. The purification of CNT was performed as the following. A total of 50mg of raw multiwalled CNT was refluxed in 150mL of concentrated nitric acid at 413K for 4h. Then, the samples were filtered, washed with distilled water, and finally dried at 333K in an oven. This purification step introduces the oxygenated functionalities onto the nanotube surface and helps CNT disperse into the aqueous solution well [46–50]. Synthesis of graphene oxide. Natural graphite powder was used to synthesize graphene oxide (GO) with a modified Hummers method that involves a strong oxidation and exfoliation process in solution [48,51–53]. It is well documented to utilize GO as the precursor of graphene (GR) to synthesize the reduced graphene oxide (RGO)-semiconductor composite photocatalysts [46,48,49,51–55]. The details for the synthesis of GO are presented in the Supporting Information. Synthesis of CdS nanowires. Uniform CdS NWs were grown through a modified solvothermal method [15,34]. In a typical process, 1.124g of cadmium diethyldithiocarbamate (Cd(S2CNEt2)2), prepared by precipitation from a stoichiometric mixture of sodium diethyldithiocarbamate trihydrate and cadmium chloride in deionized water, was added to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with a capacity of 50mL. Then, the autoclave was filled with 40mL of ethylenediamine to 80% of the total volume. The autoclave was maintained at 453K for 24h and then allowed to cool to room temperature. A yellowish precipitate was collected and washed with absolute ethanol and deionized water to remove residue of organic solvents. The final products were dried in an oven at 333K for 12h. Synthesis of 1D–1D CdS NWs-CNT NCs. The 1D–1D CdS NWs-CNT NCs were fabricated by a simple and efficient electrostatic self-assembly method at room temperature, as illustrated in Scheme 1 . In a typical synthesis, the positively charged amine-functionalized CdS NWs and a certain amount of negatively charged CNT (feed stock ratio of CNT/CdS is 1, 5, 10, 20, and 50wt%, respectively) were mixed under vigorous stirring. After mixing for 60min, the mixture was centrifuged and washed with deionized water. Then, the products were dried in an oven at 333K for 12h. For the comparison purpose, the CdS NWs-RGO NCs were also synthesized using the similar approach except that the use of GO, instead of CNT, as the carbon precursor, then autoclaved in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel at 393K for 12h in water with which GO was reduced to RGO during such a hydrothermal treatment [54]. In addition, CdS NWs modified with APTES were also used to synthesize the CdS NWs-RGO NCs as reported previously [18]; for the clarity to distinguish, this sample was called CdS NWs-RGO (APTES). 2.3 Characterization Zeta potentials (ξ) of the CdS NWs and CNT were determined by dynamic light scattering analysis (Zeta sizer 3000HSA) by taking advantage of five measurements at room temperature of 298K. In brief, 25mg of CdS NWs was diluted to 50mL deionized water to obtain a concentration of ca. 500mg/L in an aqueous solution. The crystal phase properties of the samples were analyzed with a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (XRD) using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation at 40kV and 40mA in the 2θ ranging from 5° to 80° with a scan rate of 0.02° per second. The optical properties of the samples were analyzed by UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) using a UV–vis spectrophotometer (Cary 500, Varian Co.), in which BaSO4 was employed as the internal reflectance standard. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) was used to characterize the morphology of the samples on a FEI Nova NANOSEM 230 spectrophotometer. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas were determined at 77K using Micromeritics ASAP2010 equipment. The sample was degassed at 413K for 5h and then analyzed at 77K. The relative pressure (P/P 0) range used for calculation of BET surface area was from 0.05 to 0.35. The Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was performed on a Nicolet Nexus 670 FT-IR spectrophotometer at a resolution of 4cm−1. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra for solid samples were investigated on a Cary Eclipse Fluorescence spectrophotometer with an excitation wavelength of 360nm. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed in the presence of 5.0mM K3[Fe(CN)6]/K4[Fe(CN)6] by applying an AC voltage with 5mV amplitude in a frequency range from 1Hz to 85kHz under open circuit potential conditions. 2.4 Photocatalytic activity In a typical photocatalytic reaction, a 300W Xe arc lamp (PLS-SXE 300, Beijing Perfect light Co., Ltd.) with a UV−CUT filter to cut off light of wavelength λ <420nm was used as the irradiation source. A total of 10mg of the sample and 40mg of ammonium formate were added into 40mL of the aromatic nitro compounds solution (20mgL−1) in a quartz vial. Before visible light illumination, the above suspension was stirred in the dark for 1h to ensure the establishment of adsorption–desorption equilibrium between the sample and reactant. During the process of the reaction, 4mL of sample solution was collected at a certain time interval and centrifuged to remove the catalyst completely at 12000rmp. Afterward, the solution was analyzed on a Varian ultraviolet–visible light (UV–vis) spectrophotometer (Cary-50, Varian Co.). The reactant and product identification is also confirmed by the high-performance liquid chromatographic (HPLC) analysis (Shimadzu HPLC–LC20AT equipped with a C18 column and SPD-M20A photo diode array detector). The whole experimental process was conducted under N2 bubbling at the flow rate of 80mLmin−1. Controlled photoactivity experiments using K2S2O8 as scavenger for electrons were carried out similar to the above photocatalytic selective reduction of nitro organics except that the radical scavengers were added to the reaction system [49,56]. The experimental setup was shown in the Supporting Information (Fig. S1, Supporting Information). 3 Results and discussion The CdS NWs-CNT NCs have been synthesized via a simple and efficient electrostatic self-assembly approach which can be demonstrated by the zeta potential (ξ) measurements. Fig. S2 (Supporting Information) shows zeta values of CdS NWs and CNT aqueous suspension. Fig. S2A shows that the zeta potential value of as-prepared CdS NWs is +13.7mV when dispersed in water without adding HCl or NaOH aqueous solution at pH=6, which means positively charged surface of the as-prepared CdS NWs. As CdS NWs have been synthesized via a solvothermal route in ethylenediamine as single solvent and surfactant at the temperature of 453K for 24h, the positively charged surface may be due to residual amine ions on the surface of CdS nanowires just like other amine-functionalized materials in the previous reports [12,57,58]. The Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) of CdS NWs further evidences the existence of amino group on the surface of the CdS NWs, as displayed in Fig. S3 (Supporting Information). The FT-IR peak at 3450cm−1 can be observed from CdS NWs, which is attributable to the stretching vibrations of N–H. The result provides a strong evidence for the positively charged surface of CdS NWs and is in line with the result of zeta potential measurements. The value of zeta potential for CNT measured under the same condition as that of CdS NWs, as shown in Fig. S2B (Supporting Information), is −43.4mV, which indicates a significant negatively charged surface. This is because the purification step with acids functionalizes the CNT surfaces with a large amount of carboxylic polar groups, which make the modified CNT well dispersed into the aqueous solution be negatively charged [10,48,59,60]. Thus, the natural, opposite surface charge of CNT and CdS NWs allows the fabrication of CdS NWs-CNT composite with different addition ratios of CNT via a simple, direct electrostatic self-assembly approach at room temperature, which is accomplished by dropping negatively charged CNT into the positively charged CdS NWs in an aqueous solution, as pictorially illustrated in Scheme 1. It is clear that this approach is distinguished from other synthesis processes of self-assembly methods that often need various kinds of polyelectrolytes to adjust the surface charge of materials. Fig. 1 displays the typical field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images of the CdS NWs and CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs. As seen in Fig. 1A and B, the morphology of bare CdS NWs is typically characteristic of 1D nanowires with diameter of CdS NWs in the range of ca. 50–100nm. The dimensions are highly uniform among the individual CdS NWs. With regard to CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs, it can be observed from Fig. 1C and D that CNT is cross-linked with the CdS NWs. In particular, it is worth noting that, in the direct contact interface between CdS NWs and CNT, the electrostatic attractive interaction between positively charged CdS NWs and negatively charged CNT is able to endow the two ingredients with an efficient interfacial interaction, which is beneficial for the charge carriers transfer and separation across the interfaces of CdS NWs and CNT. This consequently might improve the photocatalytic performance of the nanocomposites toward a specific photocatalytic reaction [10]. Fig. 2 depicts the XRD patterns of CdS NWs and CdS NWs-CNT NCs with different weight addition ratios of CNT (1%, 5%, 10%, 20%, and 50%) to indicate the crystalline phase of CdS NWs in the nanocomposites and the effects of CNT on the crystallinity of CdS NWs. It is clear to see that all of the CdS NWs-CNT NCs have similar XRD patterns, which can be attributed to the stable hexagonal phase CdS NWs [Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS) No. 41-1049], and the cell constants are known as a =4.136Å and c =6.713Å. The peaks at 2θ values of 24.8°, 26.5°, 28.2°, 36.6°, 43.7°, 47.8°, 50.9°, 51.8°, 52.8°, 66.8°, 69.2°, 70.9°, 72.3°, and 75.5° for CdS NWs are indexed to the (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (103), (200), (112), (201), (203), (210), (211), (114), and (105) crystal planes of greenokite structure CdS with a hexagonal phase, respectively. No typical diffraction peaks of CNT are obviously observed in the CdS NWs-CNT NCs. This is because the characteristic peak of CNT at 26.2° (Fig. S4, Supporting Information) is probably overlapped with the (002) diffraction peak of CdS NWs, which is consistent with the previous reports [46,61,62]. The optical properties of CdS NWs-CNT NCs have been measured using ultraviolet–visible light diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–vis DRS). The UV–vis DRS spectra of CdS NWs-CNT NCs are shown in Fig. 3 A. The presence of CNT affects the optical property of light absorption for the CdS NWs-CNT NCs significantly and an apparent enhancement of visible light absorption can be observed for CdS NWs-CNT NCs as compared to corresponding CdS NWs. The absorption of CdS NWs-CNT NCs in the range of 520–800nm is enhanced with the increase of the CNT contents in the nanocomposites, which is in accordance with the color change of the samples from yellow to dark green, as shown in Fig. S5 (Supporting Information). This change of light absorption properties could be attributed to the two reasons. The first one is induced by the background light absorption of CNT in the visible light region. The second one could be induced by the enhancement of surface electric charge of CdS in CdS NWs-CNT NCs because, according to the previous reports, the introduction of CNT can lead to the possible electronic transition of π→π* of CNT and n→π* between the n-orbit of the CdS and CNT [61,63,64]. The change of light absorption of CdS NWs due to its hybridization with CNT would have influence on the fundamental process of formation of electron/hole pairs and their separation in the photocatalytic process under visible light illumination. Fig. 3B shows the plots obtained via the transformation based on the Kubelka–Munk function versus the energy of light. The estimated band gap values of the samples are about 2.40, 2.37, 2.33, 2.32, 2.31, and 2.29eV approximately, corresponding to blank-CdS NWs, CdS NWs-1%CNT, CdS NWs-5%CNT, CdS NWs-10%CNT, CdS NWs-20%CNT, and CdS NWs-50%CNT, respectively. With the increase of CNT content in the nanocomposites, the estimated value of the band gap decreases. Such an analogous phenomenon has been reported in previous research works regarding semiconductor-CNT nanocomposites [46–48,61,65], which could be attributed to electronic interactions between CNT and CdS NWs. The photocatalytic performance of CdS NWs-CNT NCs has been evaluated toward selective reduction of nitro organics to corresponding amino organics in the aqueous phase under visible light irradiation using ammonium formate as quencher for photogenerated holes and N2 purge under ambient conditions, i.e., room temperature and atmospheric pressure. The UV–vis light adsorption spectra were used to monitored the conversion of 4-nitroaniline (4-NA) to 4-phenylenediamine (4-PDA) (Fig. S6, Supporting Information), during the reduction process with reaction time [57,66–68]. As shown in Fig. S6, with the reaction progressing, the absorption peak at 382nm decreases and, concomitantly, two new absorption peaks at 240nm and 300nm appear and increase, which can be ascribed to the reduction of 4-NA and the formation of 4-PDA, respectively [57,66–68]. The UV–vis spectra exhibit an isosbestic point between two absorption bands, demonstrating that there are only two principal species, 4-NA and 4-PDA. This is further corroborated by the high-performance liquid chromatographic (HPLC) analysis (Fig. S7, Supporting Information), which confirms that the product is primarily dominated by 4-PDA. Fig. 4 A shows the photocatalytic activity of bare CdS NWs and CdS NWs-CNT NCs with different weight ratios of CNT toward selective reduction of 4-NA to 4-PDA. It can be obviously observed that the weight addition ratio of CNT exhibits a significant influence on the photoactivity. The photocatalytic reduction efficiency of 4-NA follows the order: CdS NWs-5%CNT>CdS NWs-1%CNT>CdS NWs-10%CNT>CdS NWs-20%CNT>blank-CdS NWs>CdS NWs-50%CNT. It is clear that the addition of appropriate amount of CNT can enhance the photoactivity effectively. Even with a small amount addition of CNT, the photoactivity of sample is noticeably increased. For example, the photoactivity of CdS NWs-1%CNT is higher than the bare CdS NWs. In the presence of 5% amount of CNT, photocatalytic selective reduction of nitro organics to corresponding amino organics in the aqueous phase activity is the best of all, indicating the achievement of optimal synergistic interaction between CNT and CdS NWs. The process of selective reduction of 4-NA to 4-PDA was nearly completed within only 5min over CdS NWs-5%CNT under visible light irradiation. The significant enhancement of photoactivity after the hybridization of CdS NWs with CNT can be attributed to the following three factors: (i) the unique 1D–1D morphology of CdS NWs and CNT is beneficial for a fast and long-distance electron transport [10], contributing to the reduction reaction efficiency; (ii) the photogenerated electrons in the CdS NWs semiconductor under visible light irradiation can be accepted by CNT [59,69], thereby decreasing the recombination probability of the photoexcited electron–hole pairs, which will be evidenced by the later discussion; (iii) the presence of CNT is able to enhance the visible light absorption intensity as reflected by the above UV–vis DRS [60]. However, it should be noted that a further increase in the CNT content leads to a deterioration of the photoactivity performance, indicating that a synergistic interaction between CNT and CdS NWs is required in order to optimally improve the photoactivity of semiconductor CdS NWs. With the content of CNT at 20%, the photoactivity is lowered greatly. In particular, with the CNT content at 50%, the photoactivity performance is even worse than the bare CdS NWs. Thus, it can be concluded that a large percentage of black CNT is detrimental to enhance the photocatalytic performance of CdS NWs, which in fact is a universal problem for the CNT-based nanocomposites photocatalysts [59–61,70,71]. It is reasonable because the introduction of high addition amount of CNT leads to scattering of photons by surplus carbon and preventing the light from being absorbed by CdS NWs. On the other hand, the introduction of the high addition amount of CNT leads to shielding of the active sites on the photocatalyst surface and also rapidly decreases the intensity of light through the depth of the reaction solution, which is called a “shielding effect” [27,52,59,72,73]. As a consequence, a suitable content of CNT is crucial for optimizing the photoactivity of CdS NWs-CNT NCs. In most cases, independent of what kind of photocatalytic reactions is studied over semiconductor-CNT composites, the weight addition ratio of CNT is generally lower than 5% in order to reach an optimal synergistic interaction between CNT and semiconductor for the enhanced photoactivity [59,60]. To better understand the importance of interfacial interaction by electrostatic attraction between CdS NWs and CNT on efficiently improving the photoactivity, we also have prepared the CdS NWs-5%CNT analogue by a simple mechanical mixing process; for clarity, we call this sample CdS NWs-5%CNT-mixing. It is obvious that, from Fig. 4B, CdS NWs-5%CNT-mixing shows much worse photoactivity than CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs, prepared by the electrostatic assembly method, toward selective reduction of 4-NA to 4-PDA under identical reaction conditions. These results suggest that the electrostatic attractive interaction at the direct contact domain between positively charged CdS NWs and negatively charged CNT can efficiently contribute to the photogenerated charge carriers transfer across the interface over CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs, whereas this effect cannot be obtained over CdS NWs-5%CNT-mixing with poor interfacial interaction. In fact, it has been recognized that the interaction between carbon materials and semiconductor is one important factor that affects the overall photoactivities of the carbon-semiconductor composite photocatalysts [48,54,74]. To further study the similarity and difference of CNT and its carbon allotrope graphene (GR also called RGO provided that GR is obtained from the solvothermal reduction of GO) [46–48,54] in enhancing the photoactivity of semiconductor CdS NWs, we have compared the photoactivity of CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs with CdS NWs-5%RGO counterparts toward photocatalytic selective reduction of 4-NA to 4-PDA. As displayed in Fig. 4B, an overall view of the photoactivity steers us to find that, due to the hybridization of CdS NWs with CNT or RGO, both CdS NWs-5%CNT and CdS NWs-5%RGO possess higher photoactivity for the probe reactions than the bare CdS NWs. However, notably, CdS NWs-5%RGO does not exhibit superior photoactivity for selective reduction of nitro organics as compared to CdS NWs-5%CNT; indeed, CdS NWs-5%CNT shows higher photoactivity than CdS NWs-5%RGO. Therefore, it is clear that, although the introduction of RGO can increase the photocatalytic performance of the semiconductor CdS NWs for a specific reaction, it is inappropriate to ascribe the primary reason for the photoactivity enhancement of the semiconductor to the unique and prominent advantage of RGO in comparison with other carbon allotropes, e.g., CNT [46,47,52]. Despite the fact that an absolutely strict comparison between CNT and RGO on enhancing the semiconductor photoactivity is hardly reached because it is difficult to ensure all other factors influencing the photocatalytic performance are identical in contrast test, the current study at least highlights that, so far, it is hard to manifest whether RGO is wholly superior to its carbon allotrope, CNT, for the use in photocatalysis. Ongoing research efforts should be rationally paid to how to sufficiently utilize the carbon materials to enhance the semiconductor photoactivity instead of plunging into the “graphene gold rush,” similar to the case of CNT. In addition, when the photoactivity of CdS NWs-5%RGO is compared with CdS NWs-5%RGO (APTES), it is interesting to note that the latter composites constructed by using functionalized CdS NWs with APTES show the very similar photoactivity to CdS NWs-5%RGO. This indicates that modifying CdS nanowires with the positively charged polyelectrolyte APTES is a redundant process in previous report [18]. This is understandable because the amine functional groups on the surface of as-synthesized CdS NWs make it be positively charged, as evidenced by the zeta potential and FT-IR analysis (Supporting Information). To ensure if the photoactivity enhancement due to the hybridization of CNT with CdS NWs is general toward reduction of nitro organics, we have investigated the photocatalytic performance of selective reduction of other aromatic nitro compounds, including 2-nitrophenol, 4-nitrophenol, 3-nitrophenol, 4-nitrotoluene, 2-nitroaniline, and 3-nitroaniline, as displayed in Fig. 5 A–F. It is clear that such a similar trend of significantly enhanced photoactivity has been observed. Since the photocatalytic reduction efficiency is intimately related with the fate and transfer of photogenerated electrons, the highly enhanced photocatalytic performance, as observed for photoreduction of aromatic nitro organics, could be attributed to the fact that the addition of CNT into the matrix of CdS NWs would remarkably improve the fate and transfer of photogenerated electron–hole pairs from CdS NWs under visible light irradiation. Furthermore, it should be noted that the addition of ammonium formate in our reaction system serves as quencher for the photogenerated positive holes, thus offering an adequate opportunity of spatial contact between photogenerated electrons and reactants (aromatic nitro organics) [18,75]. These integrative factors would result in the increased photoactivity of CdS NWs-5%CNT as compared to the bare CdS NWs. The above inferences have been evidenced by the photoluminescence (PL) spectra and photoelectrochemical analysis, which are often used to reflect the fate and transfer of photogenerated charge carriers from a photocatalyst. The PL originates from the recombination of electron–hole pairs after a photocatalyst is irradiated so that its intensity can be used to reflect the electron–hole pairs fate photogenerated from semiconductor [46]. As displayed in Fig. 6 , the CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs show diminished PL intensity than that of bare CdS NWs and CdS NCs-5%RGO, suggesting the effectively reduced charge recombination [76]. This can be attributed to the fact that CNT can act as an “electron reservoir” to trap or shuttle the photogenerated electrons from semiconductors [59,77–79]. To further determine the advantages of CdS NCs-5%CNT over CdS NWs and CdS NCs-5%RGO in improving the charge carriers transfer, electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) Nyquist plot, a very useful tool to characterize the charge carriers migration, has also been performed. As shown in Fig. 7 , the Nyquist plots of CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs electrode exhibit the most depressed semicircles at high frequency under visible light irradiation in the three electrodes, manifesting that the more efficient transfer of charge carriers is obtained over CdS NWs-5%CNT than CdS NWs and CdS NCs-5%RGO. The increased fate and transfer of photogenerated charge carriers are in accordance with the higher photoactivity of CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs as observed above. On the other hand, in our reaction system, the photogenerated holes are scavenged by the quenching agent of ammonium formate. Thus, the improved lifetime of photogenerated electrons over CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs can effectively lead to the enhanced photoactivity toward the sequential reduction of the nitro group [80]. To further ensure the decisive role of photogenerated electrons during selective reduction of nitro organics, the controlled experiments have been performed, using K2S2O8 as scavenger for photogenerated electrons, for reduction of 4-NA over bare CdS NWs and CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs under visible light irradiation. As displayed in Fig. 8 A, when K2S2O8 is added into 4-NA in the aqueous phase over CdS NWs, it is clear to see that no conversion of 4-NA is observed under visible light irradiation. Fig. 8B shows the same phenomenon of terminating reduction of 4-NA in the aqueous phase over CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs, which indicates that the reduction reaction of aromatic nitro organics is driven by the photogenerated electrons. This is reasonable because the overall photoreduction of aromatic nitro organics to corresponding amino organics can be expressed by the following formula. The photostability of the samples is a crucial conundrum since CdS generally suffers from photocorrosion due to the oxidation of CdS by its own photogenerated holes, especially in aqueous solution [75,81]. However, it should be noted that, in our reaction system, photogenerated holes are quenched by the addition of ammonium formate in our reaction system, which is able to prevent the photocorrosion of CdS NWs during the photocatalytic reduction reaction [18]. In addition, in a previous work regarding CdS nanoparticles dotted on the surface of CNT, it was found that the photocorrosion of CdS nanoparticles in the solution could be hampered by the CNT [70]. The photostability of CdS NWs is verified by four successive recycling tests for reduction of 4-NA over CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs under visible light irradiation, as displayed in Fig. 9 . In addition, the surface area and porosity of CdS NWs and CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs have been investigated by the nitrogen adsorption–desorption. As shown in Fig. 10 , the CdS NWs and the CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs both exhibit type IV isotherm with a typical H3 hysteresis loop characteristic of mesoporous solids according to the IUPAC classification [46,82]. It can be found from Table 1 that the introduction of CNT has no significant influence on the surface area of the composites as compared to CdS NWs alone. The specific Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume are 18m2/g and 0.17cm3/g for CdS NWs, and 24m2/g and 0.10cm3/g for CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs. The introduction of CNT leads to no apparent difference of the absorption capacity, which is faithfully verified by the UV–vis spectra of 4-NA after reaching the adsorption equilibrium in the dark over CdS NWs and CdS NWs-5%CNT NCs (Fig. S8, Supporting Information). On the basis of the above discussions, a possible mechanism for photocatalytic selective reduction of nitro organics over the CdS NWs-CNT NCs can be schematically proposed in Fig. 11 . Upon the visible light (λ >420nm) irradiation with inert N2 purge atmosphere, the electrons in the valence band (VB) of CdS NWs in CdS NWs-CNT NCs are photoexcited to the conduction band (CB) of CdS NWs, leaving holes in the valence band. Due to the presence of CNT, the photogenerated electrons can transfer to CNT, which hampers the recombination of electrons and holes efficiently. On the other hand, ammonium formate as quenching agent for photogenerated holes along with N2 purge provides an anaerobic atmosphere for the reduction reaction, which can guarantee the fact that the aromatic nitro organics have no opportunity to undergo the oxidation reaction. As a result, the improved lifetime and transfer of photogenerated electrons significantly contribute to the remarkably enhanced photoactivity of CdS NWs-CNT NCs toward selective reduction of nitro organics to amino organics under ambient conditions. 4 Conclusions To sum up, a series of CdS nanowires-carbon nanotubes 1D–1D nanocomposites (CdS NWs-CNT NCs) with different addition ratios of CNT have been synthesized by a simple self-assembly method at room temperature, which is afforded by substantial electrostatic attractive interaction between positively charged CdS NWs and negatively charged CNT in an aqueous solution. This facile approach smartly utilizes the natural surface charge properties of CdS NWs and CNT to construct 1D–1D CdS NWs-CNT, which does not need the additional use of polyelectrolytes to modify the surface charge properties of materials. Importantly, it is found that CdS NWs-CNT NCs, prepared by such a very simple way, exhibit the efficient and remarkably enhanced visible light photoactivity than bare CdS NWs toward selective reduction of nitro organics to amino organics in the aqueous phase. The enhanced photoactivity over CdS NWs-CNT NCs can be ascribed to the following factors including the unique 1D–1D morphology associated with CdS NWs and CNT, the decreased recombination of the electron–hole pairs photoexcited from CdS NWs and the enhanced visible light absorption intensity, resulted from the hybridization of CdS NWs with CNT. Further, the CdS NWs-CNT NCs have higher photoactivity than CdS NWs-RGO NCs fabricated by the similar self-assembly strategy toward selective reduction of nitro organics. This work not only offers a very simple electrostatic self-assembly approach to synthesize 1D semiconductor-CNT nanocomposites as a highly efficient visible light photocatalyst for selective reduction transformation, but also underpinning the importance on how to rationally utilize the carbon materials (e.g., 1D CNT, 2D RGO) to design more efficient carbon-semiconductor composites photocatalyst for solar energy conversion, instead of joining the “graphene gold rush” similar to the case of CNT. coredata.dc:description: One-dimensional CdS nanowires-carbon nanotubes nanocomposites (1D–1D CdS NWs-CNT NCs) with different weight addition ratios of CNT have been synthesized by a very simple room temperature self-assembly method, which is afforded by electrostatic attractive interaction between positively charged CdS NWs and negatively charged CNT in an aqueous solution. Importantly, the CdS NWs-CNT NCs exhibit remarkably enhanced photoactivity toward selective reduction of aromatic nitro organics in water under visible light irradiation as compared to bare CdS NWs. The significantly enhanced photoactivity is attributed to the integrated factors of the unique 1D–1D morphology associated with CdS NWs and CNT, the efficient retardation of recombination of the photoexcited electron–hole pairs, and the enhanced visible light absorption intensity. Besides, the CdS NWs-CNT NCs exhibit higher photoactivity than CdS NWs-reduced graphene oxide (CdS NWs-RGO NCs), toward selective reduction of aromatic nitro organics. Therefore, this work not only offers a very simple room temperature approach to synthesize highly efficient 1D semiconductor-1D CNT composite photocatalyst, but also gives an example that RGO cannot readily manifest its unique and prominent advantage over CNT for specific photocatalytic application, thus underpinning the importance of rationally utilizing the carbon materials (e.g., 1D CNT, 2D RGO) to design more efficient carbon-semiconductor composite photocatalyst.
coredata.dc:title: A simple yet efficient visible-light-driven CdS nanowires-carbon nanotube 1D–1D nanocomposite photocatalyst
